modernized: I can attest that this treatment has subsequently proven successful on multiple occasions; thus, I hereby openly endorse it to my fellow countrymen for the greater benefit, as a remarkably effective remedy against all ailments resulting from excessive consumption or overindulgence.
notes:
* To maintain the connection with the previous paragraph, I preserved the implied continuity by starting with "I can attest that this treatment has subsequently proven successful" to explicitly link the outcome to the previously described Yahoo's treatment.
* The term "repletion" is somewhat archaic and was modernized to "excessive consumption or overindulgence", aiming to retain its original meaning (i.e., conditions arising from eating or drinking too much).

original: The office of Recorder to this city being vacant by the death of a very worthy gentleman, it is said, that five or six persons are soliciting to succeed him in the employment.
modernized: With the office of Recorder for this city having become vacant due to the passing of a highly respected gentleman, it is reported that five or six individuals are now seeking to succeed him in the position.
notes: None

original: I am a stranger to all their persons, and to most of their characters; which latter, I hope, will at this time be canvassed with more decency than it sometimes happeneth upon the like occasions.
modernized: I am unacquainted with all of these individuals personally, and unfamiliar with most of their reputations; hopefully, the latter will be scrutinized with greater decorum on this occasion than is sometimes the case in similar situations.
notes:
* Considered the direct connection to the previous paragraph, but found no necessary adjustments since the original text's context is self-contained.
* Chose "unacquainted" and "unfamiliar" to maintain the formal tone of the original text, while modernizing the language.

original: Therefore, as I am wholly impartial, I can with more freedom deliver my thoughts how the several persons and parties concerned ought to proceed in electing a Recorder for this great and ancient city.
modernized: Given my complete impartiality, I am at liberty to express my thoughts freely on how the various individuals and parties involved should proceed in selecting a Recorder for this great and historic city.
notes:
* Maintained the logical flow from the previous paragraph, where the author's lack of personal connection (established earlier) is now cited as the reason for their impartiality.
* Updated wording preserves the original meaning and tone:
	+ "wholly impartial" → "complete impartiality" (equivalent phrases with modernized language)
	+ "deliver my thoughts" → "express my thoughts freely" (conveys the same sense of unencumbered opinion-sharing)

original: Having thus declared what sort of persons I have always meant, under the denomination of Whigs, it will be easy to shew whom I understand by Tories.
modernized: Having thus clarified the type of individuals I have consistently referred to as Whigs, it will be straightforward to indicate who I mean by Tories.
notes: * No changes were made to party names ("Whigs" and "Tories") as they are historical terms for factions within the British political landscape (predecessors to modern Liberal and Conservative parties, respectively). Modernizing these terms could alter their original connotation.

original: Such whose principles in Church and State, are what I have above related; whose actions are derived from thence, and who have no attachment to any set of ministers, further than as these are friends to the constitution in all its parts, but will do their utmost to save their prince and country, whoever be at the helm.

notes:

* The sentence structure was slightly adjusted to improve flow while maintaining the original conditional relationships between clauses.

original: I may add, that absurd practice of cutting turf, without any regularity; whereby great quantities of restorable land are made utterly desperate, many thousands of cattle destroyed, the turf more difficult to come at, and carry home, and less fit for burning; the air made unwholesome by stagnating pools and marshes; and the very sight of such places offensive to those who ride by.
modernized: I may also note that the absurd practice of cutting turf without any regularity is particularly detrimental; as a result, large areas of reclaimable land are rendered utterly desolate, many thousands of cattle are destroyed, the turf becomes harder to access and transport home, and is of poorer quality for burning; the air is made unwholesome by stagnant pools and marshes; and the very sight of such places is offensive to those who pass by.
notes:
* I've kept "unwholesome" as it was in the original text, assuming the author intended to convey a slightly antiquated tone. If modernization of this word is desired, alternatives could be "unhealthy", "noxious", or "polluted".
* "desperate" in the original text likely means "hopeless" or "beyond repair" in this context; if clarification is needed, it could be rephrased to "irreparably damaged".

original: Neither should that odious custom be allowed, of cutting scraws, (as they call them) which is flaying off the green surface of the ground, to cover their cabins; or make up their ditches; sometimes in shallow soils, where all is gravel within a few inches; and sometimes in low ground, with a thin greensward, and sloughy underneath; which last turns all into bog, by this mismanagement.
modernized: Furthermore, the odious custom of cutting "scraws" (as they are termed) should not be tolerated; this practice involves stripping away the green surface layer of the ground to cover their cabins or construct ditches. This is particularly detrimental in areas with shallow soil, where gravel lies just a few inches beneath, and also in low-lying ground, where a thin layer of turf overlays soggy terrain, which ultimately devolves into bog due to this mismanagement.
notes:
* I've maintained the term "scraws" as it appears in the original text, assuming it's a regional or colloquialism specific to the author's context. If clarification is desired, a footnote or additional context might be helpful to explain this term.
* The modernized text aims to preserve the connection to the preceding paragraph, which criticized the irregular practice of cutting turf; this paragraph's modernization continues to convey the author's disapproval of another related, misguided custom.

original: And, I have heard from very skilful countrymen, that by these two practices in turf and scraws, the kingdom loseth some hundreds of acres of profitable land every year; besides the irreparable loss of many skirts of bogs, which have a green coat of grass, and yet are mangled for turf; and, besides the want of canals, by regular cutting, which would not only be a great convenience for bringing their turf home at an easy rate; but likewise render even the larger bogs more dry and safe, for summer pasture.
modernized: Additionally, I have been informed by very skilled countrymen that these two practices - the irregular cutting of turf and scraws - result in the kingdom losing several hundred acres of profitable land annually. This is compounded by the irreparable destruction of many bog peripheries, which, despite having a layer of grass, are nonetheless ravaged for turf. Furthermore, the lack of canals (canals being the outcome of regular cutting) not only hinders the easy and affordable transportation of turf back home but also serves to make even the larger bogs drier and safer for summer grazing.
notes:
* To maintain clarity, I've added a brief parenthetical explanation for "canals", assuming it might be an obscure term. In this context, it appears to refer to the channels or trenches created by regular turf cutting, which can also function as makeshift canals.
* The modernized text preserves the logical flow from the preceding paragraph, highlighting the author's continued critique of these practices by quantifying their detrimental effects and emphasizing the missed opportunities for improved land management.

original: This accident absolutely determined Glumdalclitch never to trust me abroad for the future out of her sight.
modernized: This incident definitively decided Glumdalclitch to never trust me out of her sight in the future.
notes:
* I preserved the original name "Glumdalclitch" as per instructions, assuming it refers to a specific individual or entity relevant to the context.

original: I had been long afraid of this resolution, and therefore concealed from her some little unlucky adventures, that happened in those times when I was left by myself.
modernized: I had been anticipating this decision with concern and had consequently kept hidden from Glumdalclitch a few unfortunate incidents that occurred during the periods when I was left on my own.
notes:

* The phrase "left by myself" has been rephrased to "left on my own" for modern clarity while preserving the original meaning.

original: Once a kite, hovering over the garden, made a stoop at me, and if I had not resolutely drawn my hanger, and run under a thick espalier, he would have certainly carried me away in his talons.
modernized: On one occasion, a kite hovering above the garden dived down towards me, and if I hadn't quickly drawn my hanger (and presumably, myself back) and rushed under a dense espalier, it would have undoubtedly swept me up in its talons.
notes:
* To maintain contextual flow with the previous paragraph, it's implied that this "little unlucky adventure" is one of the incidents the author had kept hidden from Glumdalclitch.
* I added "(and presumably, myself back)" to clarify the action of "drawn my hanger", as the original phrase might be unclear to modern readers. The addition is parenthetical to minimize alteration while enhancing understanding.
* The terms "hanger", "espalier", and "talon" have been preserved in their original form, assuming they are:
	+ "Hanger": Possibly an old term for a hook, handle, or similar, used in this context. (If clarification is needed, please provide more historical context.)
	+ "Espalier": A type of trellis or lattice supporting plants; its meaning remains relatively consistent across time.
	+ "Talon" (or Talon): An old variant spelling of "talon", referring to a hawk's or bird of prey's sharp, hooked claw.

original: Another time, walking to the top of a fresh mole-hill, I fell to my neck in the hole, through which that animal had cast up the earth, and coined some lie, not worth remembering, to excuse myself for spoiling my clothes.
modernized: On another occasion, while walking to the top of a newly formed molehill, I tumbled into the hole, falling in up to my neck, through which the animal had excavated and thrown up the earth; afterwards, I fabricated some insignificant excuse, not worth recalling, to justify the state of my soiled clothes.
notes:
* This paragraph is another "little unlucky adventure" implied to be part of the hidden incidents from Glumdalclitch, maintaining contextual flow.
* I rephrased "cast up the earth" to "excavated and thrown up the earth" for clarity on the mole's action.

original: I likewise broke my right shin against the shell of a snail, which I happened to stumble over, as I was walking alone and thinking on poor England.
modernized: Similarly, I also suffered an injury when, while walking alone and lost in thought about poor England, I stumbled upon a snail's shell and severely bruised my right shin against it.
notes:

original: However, to make a further inquiry into the truth of this observation, I doubt not but there is reason to think that a great many of those encomiums given to ancient philosophers are taken upon trust, and by a sort of men who are not very likely to be at the pains of an inquiry that would employ so much time and thinking.
modernized: Nevertheless, to further investigate the accuracy of this observation, I have no doubt that there is reason to believe many of the praises bestowed upon ancient philosophers are accepted on trust, and by a type of individuals who are unlikely to undertake an inquiry that would require such considerable time and mental effort.
notes:
* I've maintained the slightly formal tone to match the original text's 18th-century style, while still modernizing the sentence structure.
* The phrase "sort of men" is somewhat archaic but still understandable; I've rephrased it to "type of individuals" for clarity without losing the original nuance.

original: For the usual ends why men affect this kind of discourse appear generally to be either out of ostentation, that they may pass upon the world for persons of great knowledge and observation, or, what is worse, there are some who highly exalt the wisdom of those Gentile sages, thereby obliquely to glance at and traduce Divine revelation, and more especially that of the Gospel; for the consequence they would have us draw is this: that since those ancient philosophers rose to a greater pitch of wisdom and virtue than was ever known among Christians, and all this purely upon the strength of their own reason and liberty of thinking; therefore it must follow that either all revelation is false, or, what is worse, that it has depraved the nature of man, and left him worse than it found him.
modernized: For the typical motivations behind embracing this type of discourse appear to be either a desire for ostentation, aiming to impress the world with an image of profound knowledge and insight, or, more concerning, some individuals excessively extol the wisdom of those pagan sages, indirectly criticizing and undermining Divine revelation, particularly that of the Gospel. The implied conclusion they would have us draw is as follows: since those ancient philosophers allegedly attained a higher level of wisdom and virtue than ever achieved among Christians, solely through their own reason and freedom of thought, it must logically follow that either all divine revelation is false, or, more troubling, that it has corrupted human nature, leaving it worse off than before.
notes:
* I've maintained the paragraph's complex sentence structure to preserve the author's original argumentative flow, which relies on the direct connection to the preceding paragraph.
* "Gentile sages" is an archaic way of referring to non-Christian (pagan) philosophers; I've kept the phrase "pagan sages" to ensure clarity while remaining faithful to the original text.
* The modernized text aims to preserve the author's nuanced, critical tone towards those who would use ancient philosophers to undermine Divine revelation.

original: About the same time, likewise, the House of Commons advanced one considerable step towards securing us against farther impositions from our allies, resolving that the additional forces should be continued; but with a condition, that the Dutch should make good their proportion of three-fifths to two-fifths, which those confederates had so long, and in so great degree, neglected.
modernized: Around the same time, the House of Commons also took a significant step towards protecting us from further financial burdens imposed by our allies, resolving that the additional forces would be continued; however, this decision came with a condition: that the Dutch would fulfill their proportionate obligation of three-fifths to two-fifths, a commitment that these confederates had neglected for so long and to such a great extent.
notes:
* No changes were made to the original meaning, details, or terminology (e.g., "confederates" was retained as it is an 18th-century term still understandable in modern context).
* Only minor rephrasing was applied to enhance clarity and modern sentence structure.

original: The Duke of Marlborough's deduction of two and a half per cent., from the pay of the foreign troops, was also applied for carrying on the war.
modernized: Building on this development, the Duke of Marlborough's previously established deduction of two and a half percent from the pay of the foreign troops was now utilized to help fund the continuation of the war.
notes:
* I considered the direct connection to the previous paragraph when modernizing, hence the added transitional phrase "Building on this development" to maintain contextual flow.
* The original meaning and details (e.g., specific percentage, the Duke of Marlborough's deduction) were preserved.

original: Her majesty agreed to my petition, and easily got the farmer's consent, who was glad enough to have his daughter preferred at court, and the poor girl herself was not able to hide her joy.
modernized: Her Majesty approved my petition, and readily obtained the farmer's consent, who was more than happy to have his daughter favored at court; meanwhile, the young woman herself was unable to conceal her delight.

* No changes were made to the social dynamics described (e.g., the farmer's enthusiasm for his daughter being "preferred at court"), to preserve the original context.

original: My late master withdrew, bidding me farewell, and saying he had left me in a good service; to which I replied not a word, only making him a slight bow.
modernized: Immediately after, my former master took his leave, bid me farewell, and remarked that he had secured me a favorable position; in response, I remained silent, acknowledging him with only a brief bow.
notes:
* I've kept "former master" to maintain the context of a past relationship, implied by "late master" (meaning recent past or former, rather than deceased).
* The modernized text assumes continuity with the previous paragraph, preserving the implied sequence of events (i.e., something happened regarding the petition and the court favor, and now the narrator's circumstances are changing).

original: And to urge another argument of a parallel nature.
modernized: Additionally, to present another argument of a similar kind.

original: If Christianity were once abolished, how could the freethinkers, the strong reasoners, and the men of profound learning, be able to find another subject so calculated in all points whereon to display their abilities?
modernized: Similarly, if Christianity were to be abolished, how could freethinkers, rigorous rationalists, and scholars of great erudition find another topic that is equally well-suited on all fronts for showcasing their intellectual capabilities?
notes:
* Considering this paragraph directly follows the modernized "Additionally, to present another argument of a similar kind", the word "Similarly" has been used to maintain the connection and indicate the parallel nature of the arguments.
* Translations:
	+ "strong reasoners" to "rigorous rationalists" (to convey intense or robust reasoning)
	+ "men of profound learning" to "scholars of great erudition" (to maintain the emphasis on deep knowledge, with "erudition" implying extensive, specialized learning) 
	+ "calculated in all points" to "equally well-suited on all fronts" (to preserve the idea of something being optimally positioned or suited for a particular purpose, in this case, showcasing abilities)

original: What wonderful productions of wit should we be deprived of, from those whose genius by continual practice hath been wholly turned upon raillery and invectives against religion, and would therefore never be able to shine or distinguish themselves upon any other subject!
modernized: What remarkable works of intellectual wit would we be denied, from individuals whose creative genius, honed through constant practice, has been entirely focused on ridiculing and criticizing religion, and as a result, would likely never excel or make a notable impact on any alternative topic?
notes:
* To maintain the connection with the previous paragraph, the modernized text aims to preserve the flow of ideas, emphasizing the consequence of Christianity's abolition on the intellectual landscape.
* Translations:
	+ "wonderful productions of wit" to "remarkable works of intellectual wit" (to convey a sense of impressive, clever creations)
	+ "raillery and invectives" to "ridiculing and criticizing" (to update the language while retaining the meaning: "raillery" implies mocking or satirical speech, and "invectives" means vehement, abusive criticism)
	+ "would therefore never be able to shine or distinguish themselves" to "would likely never excel or make a notable impact" (to preserve the idea that these individuals' skills are so specialized that they'd struggle to stand out in other areas)

original: We are daily complaining of the great decline of wit among us, and would we take away the greatest, perhaps the only topic we have left?
modernized: We constantly lament the significant decline of wit in our society, and yet, would we eliminate the most substantial, possibly the only, subject we have remaining that still inspires it?
notes:
* The modernized text maintains the flow of ideas from the previous paragraphs, highlighting the ironic consequence of removing Christianity as a topic.
* Translations:
	+ "daily complaining" to "constantly lament" (to convey a sense of ongoing, frequent expression of discontent)
	+ "great decline of wit" to "significant decline of wit" (to update the language while preserving the emphasis on the extent of the decline)
	+ "take away the greatest, perhaps the only topic" to "eliminate the most substantial, possibly the only, subject" (to retain the nuance of "perhaps", which introduces a hint of uncertainty or room for debate) 
	+ No changes were made to core concepts, names, or references, as none were present in this paragraph.

original: Who would ever have suspected Asgil for a wit, or Toland for a philosopher, if the inexhaustible stock of Christianity had not been at hand to provide them with materials?
modernized: Who would have ever suspected Asgil of being witty, or Toland of being a philosopher, if the boundless resources of Christianity hadn't been readily available to supply them with material?
notes:
* The modernized text preserves the author's rhetorical question and the connection to the previous paragraph's discussion on wit and topics.
* Translations:
	+ "inexhaustible stock" to "boundless resources" (to convey an abundant, limitless supply of material)
	+ "at hand" to "readily available" (to update the phrase while maintaining the sense of convenience and accessibility)
	+ No changes were made to:
		- Names: Asgil and Toland are preserved as they are specific individuals being referenced (likely John Toland, a philosopher, but Asgil's identity is less clear without more context).
		- Core concepts: The author's point about Christianity providing material for wit and philosophical discussion remains intact.

original: What other subject, through all art or nature, could have produced Tindal for a profound author, or furnished him with readers?
modernized: What other topic, spanning the entirety of art and nature, could have established Tindal as a profoundly insightful author, or provided him with an audience?
notes:
* The modernized text maintains the author's inquiry and the flow of ideas from the previous paragraphs, questioning alternative subjects that could have propelled certain individuals to prominence.
* Translations:
	+ "through all art or nature" to "spanning the entirety of art and nature" (to convey an exhaustive scope, encompassing all aspects of both domains)
	+ "produced Tindal for a profound author" to "established Tindal as a profoundly insightful author" (to update the language while emphasizing the subject's role in Tindal's reputation for depth)
	+ "furnished him with readers" to "provided him with an audience" (to use more contemporary phrasing for conveying the idea of attracting those who engage with his work)
* Assumption:
	+ Tindal is likely referring to Matthew Tindal, a 17th-18th century English deist writer, given the context and time period. If incorrect, please provide additional context for accurate handling.

original: It is the wise choice of the subject that alone adorns and distinguishes the writer.
modernized: It is the astute selection of the subject that solely lends distinction and prestige to the writer.
notes:
* The modernized text preserves the author's concise statement, which serves as a concluding remark or a general principle following the previous specific examples.
* Translations:
	+ "wise choice" to "astute selection" (to convey discerning judgment; "astute" implies sharpness and keenness in decision-making)
	+ "alone adorns and distinguishes" to "solely lends distinction and prestige" (to update the language while maintaining the emphasis on the subject's singular impact on the writer's reputation)
* Observations:
	+ This paragraph appears to shift from specific examples (Asgil, Toland, Tindal) to a broader, more universal statement about the importance of subject choice in elevating a writer's stature.
	+ The tone seems to underscore the author's previous points, implying that the subject of Christianity has been instrumental in conferring distinction upon certain writers.

original: For, had a hundred such pens as these been employed on the side of religion, they would have immediately sunk into silence and oblivion.
modernized: For if a hundred writers of similar caliber to these had instead taken up the defense of religion, they would have instantly fallen into obscurity and silence.
notes:
* The modernized text maintains the author's hypothetical scenario, which serves as a contrasting thought experiment following the previous statement on subject choice.
* Translations:
	+ "had a hundred such pens" to "if a hundred writers of similar caliber" (to update the language; "pens" is an archaic term for writers, and "similar caliber" conveys equivalence in skill or talent)
	+ "been employed on the side of religion" to "had instead taken up the defense of religion" (to clarify the action and intent; "employed on" is a more antiquated way of expressing engagement with a topic)
	+ "sunk into silence and oblivion" to "fallen into obscurity and silence" (to convey the same outcome; "sunk" implies a sudden, dramatic descent, while "fallen" maintains this sense in modern language)
* Observations:
	+ This paragraph presents a counterfactual scenario, highlighting the author's belief that the writers mentioned earlier (Asgil, Toland, Tindal) owe their notoriety to criticizing Christianity rather than defending it.
	+ The contrast between this paragraph and the previous one reinforces the author's central argument about the significance of subject choice in determining a writer's impact.

original: It is true I should be very loth the bright example of your Lordship's virtues should be lost to after-ages, both for their sake and your own; but chiefly because they will be so very necessary to adorn the history of a late reign; and that is another reason why I would forbear to make a recital of them here; because I have been told by wise men that as dedications have run for some years past, a good historian will not be apt to have recourse thither in search of characters.
modernized: It is true that I would be reluctant for the exemplary virtues of Your Lordship to be lost to future generations, both for their benefit and yours; but primarily because they will be especially necessary to enhance the historical account of a recent reign. This is another reason I would refrain from recounting them here; as I have been advised by wise individuals that, given the trend of dedications in recent years, a good historian is unlikely to consult them when seeking to understand character profiles.
notes:
* "after-ages" was modernized to "future generations" for clarity and natural flow.
* "late reign" is retained as is, assuming it refers to a recently concluded monarch's rule; if more context is needed for precise understanding, please provide. 
* "dedications" appears to refer to introductory or dedicatory sections in historical works; the modernized text maintains this interpretation.

original: About this time the hidden sparks of animosity between the two brothers, buried but not extinguished in the last peace, began to flame out into new dissensions.
modernized: Around this time, the underlying sparks of animosity between the two brothers, which had been suppressed but not eliminated by the previous reconciliation, started to ignite into fresh conflicts.
notes: None. (Added for consistency, as per your request; no actual notes or questions are present.)

original: Duke Robert had often sent his complaints to the King for breach of articles, but without redress, which provoked him to expostulate in a rougher manner, till at length he charged the King in plain terms with injustice and perjury, but no men are found to endure reproaches with less temper than those who most deserve them, the King, at the same time filled with indignation, and stung with guilt, invaded Normandy a second time, resolving to reduce his brother to such terms as might stop all further complaints.

However, it is often the case that those who are most culpable are also the least capable of enduring rebukes with composure; accordingly, the King, simultaneously consumed by indignation and stung by guilt, launched a second invasion of Normandy, determined to bring his brother to terms that would silence all future complaints.
notes:
* I maintained the paragraph's original tone and emphasis on the King's reaction, which is partly based on his own guilt.
* The phrase "with less temper than those who most deserve them" is somewhat idiomatic; I rephrased it for clarity while preserving its original implication.

original: He had already taken several strong holds, by force either of arms or of money, and intending entirely to subdue the duchy, gave orders to have twenty thousand men immediately raised in England, and sent over to him.
modernized: Having already seized control of several key strongholds through either military might or financial influence, with the aim of completely subjugating the duchy, he issued directives to rapidly mobilize twenty thousand men in England and dispatch them to reinforce his position.
notes:
* I preserved the implied sequence of events from the previous paragraph (invasion already underway) by using "Having already seized control".
* The original text's concise language is maintained in the modernized version, with minimal rephrasing for clarity.

original: The Duke, to defend himself against these formidable preparations, had recourse again to his old ally the King of France, who very readily advanced with an army to his assistance, as an action wherein he could every way find his own accounts, for, beside the appearance of glory and justice by protecting the injured, he fought indeed his own battle, by preserving his neighbouring state in the hands of a peaceful prince, from so powerful and restless an enemy as the King of England, and was largely paid for his trouble into the bargain, for King William, either loth to engage in a long and dangerous war, or hastened back by intelligence of some troubles from Wales, sent offers to his army, just ready to embark for Normandy, that upon payment of ten shillings a man they might have leave to return to their own homes.
modernized: To counter the formidable preparations against him, the Duke once again turned to his long-standing ally, the King of France, who promptly marched to his aid with an army, as this action served the French King's interests on multiple fronts. By protecting the aggrieved Duke, he garnered the appearance of glory and justice, while in reality, he was fighting to preserve his neighboring state under the rule of a peaceful prince, shielding it from the powerful and restless King of England. Moreover, the French King was amply compensated for his efforts, as King William - either reluctant to embark on a protracted and perilous war or hastened back by news of disturbances in Wales - extended an offer to his army, poised on the verge of departing for Normandy: in exchange for a payment of ten shillings per man, they were granted leave to return to their homes.
notes:
* I broke up the long original sentence into two for improved readability, while maintaining the logical flow and connections between ideas.
* The phrase "find his own accounts" is somewhat archaic; I rephrased it to "served the French King's interests on multiple fronts" to convey the same meaning in more contemporary language.

original: This bargain was generally accepted, the money was paid to the King of France, who immediately withdrew his troops, and King William, now master of the conditions, forced his brother to a peace upon much harder terms than before.
modernized: This offer was widely accepted, with the payment made to the King of France, who promptly withdrew his forces in response; subsequently, with the upper hand, King William compelled his brother to accept a peace agreement on significantly more stringent terms than those previously proposed.
notes:
* I maintained the concise and direct nature of the original text in the modernized version.
* The phrase "now master of the conditions" is somewhat idiomatic; I rephrased it to "with the upper hand" to convey the same meaning (King William having gained a strategic advantage) in more contemporary language.

original: That Prince, as well as his minister, Mons. de Torcy, either felt, or affected, so much resentment of the usage the latter had met at The Hague and Gertruydenberg, that they appeared fully determined against making any application to the States, where the same persons continued still in power, of whose treatment they so heavily complained.
modernized: That Prince, as well as his minister, Monsieur de Torcy, either genuinely felt or outwardly displayed such strong resentment towards the treatment the latter had received at The Hague and Gertruydenberg, that they seemed entirely resolved against making any overtures to the States, given that the same individuals who had perpetrated this treatment remained in power.
